SCOPE





The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. The following areas are addressed in this summary:



?    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

?    Stationary Source Activities and Regulated Substances Handled

?    Worst-Case and Alternative-Case Release Scenarios

?    Prevention Program

?    Five-Year Accident History

?    Emergency Response Program

?    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Crowne Cold Storage LLC. is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program.  Crowne Cold Storage LLC. has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. 



The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.



Federal regulations require reporting when there is a significant release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.

State regulations require reporting when there is an significant release of ammonia or a threat of signifcant release of ammonia.  



Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation or local first aid to anyone.



All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedures that may prevent future incidents.



Small releases which do not pose a threat will be considered incidental and do not require an emergency respons

e such as a packing leak. The leak will be repaired and an internal incident report completed.



If responders are on site releases of more than 25 ppm may result in immediately shutting down the ammonia system depending on the location of the release. Responders will investigate the release and report to the General Manager, Safety and Maintenance Management the location, extent of possible impact, level of risk and recommended actions for relocation, shelter in place or evacuaton of personnel and receptors.



Releases less than 25 PPM shall result in immediately calling the General Manager, Safety Manager and the Maintenance Manager, if not on site, for instructions. Responders will investigate the release and report to General, Safety and Maintenance Management the location, extent of possible impact, level of risk and recommended actions.



The facility utilizes inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment on an ongoing basis and prior to seasonal startup. These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite personnel, registered engineers, refrigeration experts, and certified refrigeration contractors as required review the equipment.



STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. facility provides product processing, packaging, cooling, and short-term storage for nuts and fruit. This stationary ammonia system is operated continuously but operations vary dependent on product handled and growing season.

The facility is located in a Rural Area of Tulare County. The total ammonia inventory in the closed loop ammonia refrigeration system exceeds the Federal and State thresholds and therefore falls under RMP and PSM (CalARP) requirements.

The refrigeration systems are direct, mechanical refrigeration systems. The original facility was built in 2005 and expanded and modified in 2007/2008 and 2011. 

The ammonia equipment is located o

utside, inside the engine room and in the Refrigerated Rooms.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT

The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures. The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe. 

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. In addition the Main Plant Systems are separated by walls and distance. Furthermore as the refrigerant escapes pressure will decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.

The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM Manual. The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.



Key objectives of the Crowne Cold Storage LLC. Prevention Program are briefly described below:

1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)

2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system.  The evaluation considers a number of potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by Crowne Cold Storage, LLC..  (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Mechanical Integrity Elements).

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and maintained and

how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Mechanical Integrity, and Incident Investigation Elements.) 

4) Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system.  Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. certifies operators following completion of operator training and Crowne Cold Storage, LLC.'s confirmation of the operator's ability apply what they have learned.  (Addressed under Training Element.)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation Element)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by Crowne Cold Storage, LLC.'s Management of Change Procedure.



If a mechanical change is required and for maintenance contracts, Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other "Hot Work" occurs close to the refrigeration system, a Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the

possibility of a fire. 

Following completion of a mechanical change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be started. (These areas are addressed under Management of Change, Contractor Qualifications, Hot Work Permit, and Pre-Start-up Safety Review Elements.)

7) Verification of compliance with the RMP/PSM program.  This self-audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the Prevention Program (and the Risk Management Program) has been implemented and properly documented by Crowne Cold Storage LLC. personnel.  Crowne Cold Storage LLC. has established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, which the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit chapter.)   

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under Crowne Cold Storage, LLC.'s Injury and Illness Prevention Program)



INJURY AND ILLNESS/ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

This facility follows the EPA's 40CFR68 Risk Management Plan and OSHA's 29CFR1910.119 Process Safety Management Program.  In addition the plan satisfies the State of California's Injury and Illness Prevention Program requirements CCR Title 8 3203.

In California, every employer is required by law to provide a safe and healthful workplace to his/her employees. In accordance with the California Code of Regulations, Crowne Cold Storage LLC. has an effective written Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP). 



The IIPP is a written plan that covers the following elements:

A?    Management commitment/assignment of responsibilities 

A?    Safety communications system with employees 

A?    System for assuring employee compliance with safe work practices 

A?    Scheduled inspections/evaluation system 

A?    Accident investigation 

A?    Procedures for correcting unsafe/unhealthy conditions 

A?    Safety and health training and instruction 

A?    Recordkeeping and documentation 



The IIPP includes procedures that personnel must and are put into practice. It is both the employerA

?s and employee's responsibility to control potential workplace hazards and correct hazardous conditions or practices as they occur or are recognized. The program includes a system for personnel to communicate with management on matters relating to occupational safety and health, including provisions designed to encourage employees to inform the management of hazards at the worksite without fear of reprisal.

The safety communications system, including the elements of the IIPP, are readily available and understandable to all affected employees. 

The safety communication system includes:

A?    Meetings 

A?    Training programs 

A?    Postings 

A?    Written communications 

A?    A system for anonymous notification by employees about hazards 

A?    Labor/management safety and health committees 

A?    Tail gate or tool box meetings



In addition to the above, during Construction the IIPP requires that Manager's conduct A toolbox or tailgate safety meeting with their crews at least every ten working days to emphasize safety. Managers also need to hold periodic meetings to discuss safety problems and accidents that have occurred.



The completed IIPP is filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices



Program Consolidation

The documentation requirements of these programs have been consolidated in the documenting and record filing process. 

The documents and records are kept as identified in each element of the program for the current year and then archived in the current year archive binder.

The following identifies the practices and procedures for:

    Process Safety Information

    Process Hazard Analysis

    Operating Procedures

    Training

    Mechanical Integrity

    Management of Change

    Pre-Startup Review

    Compliance Audits

    Incident Investigations

    Employee Participation

    Hot Works

    Contractors



Process Safety Information

Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, mainta

in, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as MSDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, IIAR safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, ventilation system design, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipment specifications, electrical classifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.

See the Prevention Program Element 1 for the complete information

The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office



Process Hazard Analysis

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the A?What-ifA? checklist.  This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.

See Element 2 of the Prevention Program for the complete guidelines

The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices



Technical Operating Specifications and Standard Operating Procedures

The Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) and Standard Operating Procedures (SOPA?s) are provided for each compressor, condenser, ammonia vessel, oil pot, and evaporator etc. Topics include general information such items as;

A?    Objectives 

A?    Special hazards 

A?    Location 

A?    Safety equipment needed 

A?    P&IDA?s  and Block Flow Diagrams

A?    Technical operating specifications, 

A?    Electrical classifications 

A?    Step-by-step

procedures

A?    Specific warnings & PPE 

The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown. Various other safety programs and procedures are included.

See the Prevention Program Element 3 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.

Training

All employees who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the MSDS, routine refrigeration system operation, emergency refrigeration system operation, emergency and normal refrigeration safety practices, and the individualA?s role in the emergency response plan or action plan. Refresher training is performed no less then every three years.

See the Prevention Program Element 4 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Human Resources Office.



Mechanical Integrity

The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity Audit program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition.   Inspections, and ongoing maintenance based on industry standards are performed on all compressors, condensers, evaporators, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief/vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps etc.

See the Prevention Program Element 5 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



Management of Change

The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even A?replacement in kindA?) be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before st

artup and trained in the proper procedures.

See the Prevention Program Element 6 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



Pre-Startup Review

Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.

See the Prevention Program Element 7 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



Compliance Audits

To insure that all the other 12 areas of PSM program are followed, the company requires compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years. Resubmission of the RMP shall be done according to requirements.

See the Prevention Program Element 8 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



Incident Investigation

An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of ammonia. The purpose is to gain information that could prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency response plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated promptly using a trained team. The findings and recommendations will be studied and appropriate corrective action taken.

See the Prevention Program Element 9 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



Employee Participation

The Employee Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community as a whole.  As a general rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are

more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the PSM Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phase of the PSM program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.

Community involvement is through coordination and cooperation with the local Fire department and CUPA.

See the Prevention Program Element 10 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



Hot Work and Safe Work Practices

This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done outside the shop area. The Maintenance Manager reviews and issues the permits to insure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operations.

See the Prevention Program Element 11 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



Contractors and Contractor Qualifications

This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process or the system. The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the ammonia process, that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractorA?s safety record is considered in reviewing the bids. 

See the Prevention Program Element

12 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office.



A-5 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years that meet the standard of State or Federal regulations.  



A-6    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Response Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 

Facility personnel have coordinated with responding outside agencies such as Richgrove Fire and Tulare County Environmental Health. The facilities emergency response plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 

The facility has coordinated with outside parties through drills, communication and attendance at Ammonia and Chemical Safety Days. Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency. In addition Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release.

Detailed plans (emergency action plans) have been developed to assist responding facility personnel.  All areas (zones) inside the building can be brought under control within 20 minutes of any ammonia emergency or breakdown if personnel are on site.  Small releases can be brought under control immediately.  

The emergency release response plan for all releases is to gain access to the shut down valves and switches for the system with the release.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area the entire ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate.  The appropriate shut down switches are identified at the facility.  

For Hazardous Materials Responders do not enter an IDLH condition. Responders are trained

to the Air Purifying Respirator level and trained to retreat at (300 PPM) for ammonia. Facility responders will assist outside agencies during larger releases. All personnel not trained to respond will evacuate to the meeting areas and be accounted for.

The Federal and California Emergency Planning Regulations considered in this program include:

    EPA Risk Management Plan

    OSHA Emergency Action Plan

    OSHA Process Safety Standard

    EPA Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know

    Contingency Pla



A-7    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns at this facility.  The prevention program has been updated as a result of recent addition/changes of equipment.  Several PHA studies were conducted at Crowne Cold Storage, LLC. and the study team made recommendations for additional safety.

The following list includes approved scheduled improvements to reduce accidental releases either in process or planned for at this time.  



Add a corrosion prevention program to the Mechanical Integrity Element

Complete labeling of equipment and piping per IIAR 114

Install a crash bar on the engine room man door

Install an SOP in the Emergency Control Box



Reference the latest PHA for additional recommendations
